grip.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the way you hold something tightly, or your ability to do this
grip.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Hold the microphone in a firm grip and keep it still.
She felt her wrist caught in a vice-like grip.
Don’t loosen your grip on the rope or you’ll fall.
He released his grip and stepped back.
grip.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: power and control over someone or something
grip.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Stalin’s determination to keep an iron grip on Eastern Europe
By 1979 South Africa was tightening its grip on Namibia.
The recession could be avoided if business keeps a firm grip on its costs.
grip.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: She was losing her grip on reality.
I’m just trying to get a grip on what’s happening.
grip.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a special part of a handle that has a rough surface so that you can hold it firmly without it slipping
grip.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: My racquet needs a new grip.
grip.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the ability of something to stay on a surface without slipping
grip.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: boots which give a good grip
grip.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: someone whose job is to move the cameras around while a television show or film is being made
grip.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: a bag or case used for travelling
grip.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: a firm/tight grip
The streets were crowded and she kept a tight grip on her bag.
a strong grip
Maggie took the boy's arm in a strong grip.
a good grip
The rocks were wet and slippery and it was difficult to get a good grip.
an iron/vice-like grip
Victor took hold of her wrist in an iron grip.
have a grip
You need to have a good grip on your tennis racket.
get a grip
I got a good grip on the rope and pulled myself up.
take a grip
Mitch took a firm grip on her arm.
tighten your grip/your grip tightens
She tightened her grip on her son’s hand.
loosen/relax your grip
Lee loosened his grip on the dog’s collar.
release your grip
The guard released his grip on the prisoner and pushed him into the cell.
lose your grip
He shoved Higgins out of the way without losing his grip on the gun.
grip.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I gripped the rail and tried not to look down.
The woman moved closer to Beth, gripping her arm tightly.
grip.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to have a strong effect on someone or something
grip.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: a country gripped by economic problems
Panic suddenly gripped me when it was my turn to speak.
grip.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to hold someone’s attention and interest
grip.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: a story that really grips you
grip.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: if something grips a surface, it stays on it without slipping
grip.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Radial tires grip the road well.
